node.-overall-formulation: ((title "Risk formulation") (headings (("RISKS BEING FORMULATED (Problem risks)" 2)("Risk triggers (Precipitating factors)" 2) ("Persistent contextual factors (Perpetuating)" 2) ("Past factors (Historical, Pre-existing or Predisposing)" 2) ("Protective factors" 2))))
node.-help: Please note: Risks should be assessed in the context of the person's circumstances following the assessment. This may be the same as the current circumstances but if, for example, they are being referred elsewhere or discharged, the risks should be considered for the new situation.

node.-_FIXME: TODO - replace mg-deviation-threshold attrib with real a real version
node.-question: In your judgement, what is the risk that the person will attempt suicide?
node.-help: Consider the likelihood in the context of the person's circumstances after the assessment if no further action is taken.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's risk of suicide?

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever made a suicide attempt? If yes, the questions about them should be answered with reference to the attempts in general rather than any specific one, unless otherwise stated.

node.-question: When was the most recent suicide attempt?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-filter-q: Has there been more than one suicide attempt?
node.-auto-answer: [NO suic-first-occ suic >> sui-specific >> suic-past-att >> suic-occur >> suic-most-rec][NO suic-how-many "1"]

node.-question: When was the first suicide attempt?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases, the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-question: How have the suicide attempts been changing in frequency over the last two years?
Approximately how many suicide attempts have there been?

node.-label: preparation and seriousness of suicide attempts
suicide note written for one or more previous attempts
node.-question: Was a suicide note written for any previous or current suicide attempts?

node.-label: chance of discovery after suicide attempts
node.-question: Did the person try to hide any suicide attempt, to make sure it was not stopped?
node.-help: Consider whether anyone was given any prior warning about an intended attempt or whether the person made sure he or she will not be found accidentally by someone (eg no people around, not expecting anyone).
node.-scale-type: ((left "no hiding") (right "tried very hard to hide attempts"))

node.-question: How lethal was the most serious method used by the person in any of the suicide attempts (i.e. how likely to succeed in killing the person without any intervention)?
node.-help: For example, hanging or jumping off a high building will be maximally lethal but self-stabbing or overdosing, less lethal depending exactly how it was done (eg number of pills, type of pills).

node.-label: person's current perspective on suicide attempts
thoughts/feelings related to previous suicide attempts
How much did the person want to succeed with the suicide attempts
node.-question: Do you believe the person wanted the suicide attempts to succeed at the time?
node.-help: Did he or she immediately regret any of the attempts or wish they had succeeded? Was the person surprised to be alive afterwards?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no desire to succeed") (right "really wanted to succeed"))

node.-label: regret about trying to complete suicide
node.-question: How much does the person fail to show any regret or remorse over having tried to complete suicide in the past?
node.-help: This applies to the person's current feelings and includes embarrassment or shame, regret that suicide was attempted, or wishing that the suicide was successful.

node.-label: insight into lethality of previous suicide attempts
node.-question: Does the person lack awareness about how dangerous the suicide attempts were?
node.-scale-type: ((left "aware of the danger") (right "completely unaware of the danger"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's current intention to complete suicide?

node.-label: plans and methods for completing suicide
node.-filter-q: Does the person have any plans for making a future suicide attempt?
node.-help: Answer yes if people have said anything about how they might end their lives.

node.-question: Can the person easily carry out the suicide plan (consider realism of plan and access to means of putting it into action)?
node.-help: Consider the person's occupation (eg doctor, vet, farmer), access to equipment (eg weapon, bleach, rope, gun, drugs), availability of suitable locations and contexts (eg being alone, high cliffs/buildings nearby), whether assistance has been obtained by anyone else, and collusion such as a suicide pact.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no chance of carrying out plan") (right "extremely easy to carry out plan"))

node.-label: physical steps taken to implement suicide plan
node.-question: Has the person taken steps towards carrying out the suicide plan?
node.-help: For example: researching the means of suicide, obtaining the objects for carrying it out (hoarding drugs, getting hosepipe for carbon monoxide poisoning, buying rope or cord), rehearsing the planned suicide.

node.-label: potential lethality of prospective suicide method
node.-question: How likely is the chosen method to succeed?
node.-help: For example, hanging or jumping off a high building will be maximally lethal but self-stabbing or overdosing, less lethal depending exactly how it was done (eg number of pills, type of pills). Consider also the likelihood of someone intervening to prevent success.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no chance of succeeding") (right "extremely likely to succeed"))

node.-label: informed someone about intention to complete suicide
node.-question: Has the person told anyone about an intention to complete suicide?
node.-help: This includes making threats or talking about intentions to complete suicide.

node.-label: end-of-life preparations for intended suicide act
node.-question: Has the person made end-of-life preparations matching those that would cause you most concern about suicide risk (eg written a will, sorted finances, put house in order, written suicide note)?
Does the person have a pattern of self-harming that indicates suicidal intention?
node.-help: This includes self harming behaviour that is failing to provide any relief to the person's situation, no reassurance about future behaviour, a detrimental change in the pattern of attempts (eg escalating frequency of attempts, methods involved), and whether the method used is so dangerous as to be likely to result in death (eg lethal laceration, excessively reckless driving).

node.-question: What effect do the person's spiritual/religious values, beliefs, or attitudes to dying have on risk of suicide?
Do you have reason to be concerned about anything that could trigger suicide attempts?
Is the person exposed to feelings or circumstances that may trigger a suicide attempt?
node.-help: Consider relevant emotions such as desperation, anguish, agitation, anxiety, frustration, compulsion, feeling rejected, external triggers of previous suicide attempts, mental health problems, relationship triggers (eg argument, row), changes to relationships (eg divorce, break up of relationship, loss of or change of carer ), alcohol misuse, media influence (eg copycat behaviour), their mental state (eg any dilemmas that can't be resolved), or their current setting (eg police station, custody), change in environment such as going into care or being released from care.

node.-label: potential triggers match those that previously caused suicide attempts
node.-question: Do the person's current feelings or circumstances match those that are known to have triggered any previous suicide attempts?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no previous attempts") (right "current feelings/circumstances identical to those in a previous attempt"))

node.-question: Has there been any history of suicide attempts in the person's family?

node.-filter-q: Is the person having suicidal thoughts or fantasies?

node.-question: Does the person lack ability to control suicidal thoughts or fantasies?

node.-label: content of suicidal ideation indicates high risk
node.-question: Does the content of the suicidal thoughts or fantasies make it more likely the person will attempt suicide?
node.-help: What are the thoughts or fantasies about and how does the content raise alarm bells about suicide risk?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no change to the likelihood") (right "greatly increased likelihood"))

node.-question: How often do the suicidal thoughts or fantasies occur?

node.-label: strength, intensity, intrusiveness, and persistence of suicidal ideation
node.-question: How persistent, intrusive, or intense are the suicidal thoughts or fantasies?
node.-help: Think about how much the suicidal thoughts overwhelm any other thoughts and how real they seem.
node.-scale-type: ((left "thoughts hardly noticed") (right "can't think about anything else"))

node.-question: In your judgement, what is the risk that the person will self-harm?
node.-help: Consider the likelihood in the context of the person's circumstances after the assessment if no further action is taken.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's risk of self-harming?

node.-label: past and current episodes of self-harm
node.-filter-q: Has the person ever engaged in self-harming behaviour? If yes, the questions about them should be answered with reference to the general episodes rather than any specific one, unless otherwise stated.

node.-question: Does the person display evidence of recent self-harming injuries?
node.-help: Consider cuts, burns, ligature marks, etc.

node.-question: When was the most recent self-harm episode?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-filter-q: Has there been more than one self-harm episode?
node.-auto-answer: [NO sh-first-time-ep sh >> sh-specific >> sh-past-curr-ep >> sh-occ-of-ep >> sh-most-rec-ep]

node.-question: When was the first self-harm episode?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-question: How often do the episodes of self-harm occur?
Have the self-harm episodes changed in frequency over the last year?

node.-label: chance of being helped after self-harming
node.-question: Does the person try to hide any self-harming?
node.-help: Consider whether anyone was given any prior warning about an intended attempt or whether the person made sure he or she will not be found accidentally by someone (eg no people around, not expecting anyone).
node.-scale-type: ((left "no hiding") (right " tries very hard to hide self-harming"))

node.-question: In general, how likely is it that the chosen self-harm methods could lead to death?
node.-help: For example, hanging or jumping off a high building will be maximally lethal but self-stabbing or overdosing, less lethal depending exactly how it was done (eg number of pills, type of pills, degree of cuts and their location).

node.-question: Have the self-harming methods suddenly changed?
node.-help: Think about whether the normal method of self-harming has changed to something different in the last few days. Unfamiliarity with the method can have unpredictable or dangerous outcomes.

node.-label: self-harming not a cry for help
node.-question: How much are the self-harming episodes more than a cry for help (driven by the underlying problem rather than trying to get help with it)
node.-help: Think about how the self-harming is being used. Is it to show others the person needs help or is it a way of coping with their problems alone?
node.-scale-type: ((left "purely to get help") (right "nothing to do with getting help"))

node.-label: self-harm helping to cope with difficulties
node.-question: Did the self-harm episodes help the person cope with difficulties?
Do you have reason to be concerned about anything that could trigger self-harm?
Is the person exposed to feelings or circumstances that may trigger self-harming?
node.-help: Consider relevant emotions such as desperation, anguish, agitation, anxiety, frustration, compulsion, feeling rejected, external triggers of previous suicide attempts, mental health problems, relationship triggers (eg argument, row), changes to relationships (eg divorce, break up of relationship, loss of or change of carer ), alcohol misuse, media influence (eg copycat behaviour), their mental state (eg any dilemmas that can't be resolved), or their current setting (eg police station, custody), change in environment such as going into care or being released from care.

node.-label: potential triggers match those previously triggering self-harm
node.-question: Do the person's current feelings or circumstances match those that are known to have triggered any previous episodes of self harm?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no previous self-harming") (right "current feelings/circumstances identical to those in previous self-harming"))

node.-question: Has there been any history of self-harm in the person's family?

node.-filter-q: Is the person having self-harming thoughts or fantasies?

node.-question: How often do the self-harming thoughts or fantasies occur?

node.-label: strength, intensity, intrusiveness, and persistence of self-harm ideation
node.-question: How persistent, intrusive, and intense are the self-harming thoughts?
node.-help: Think about how much the self-harming thoughts overwhelm any other thoughts and how real they seem.
node.-scale-type: ((left "thoughts hardly noticed") (right "can't think about anything else"))

node.-label: harm to others or damage to property
node.-question: In your judgement, what is the risk that the person will cause harm to people/animals or damage property?
node.-help: Consider the likelihood and consequences in the context of the person's circumstances after the assessment if no further action is taken.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's risk of harm to others or destructive behaviour?

node.-label: past and current episodes of harm or damage
node.-filter-q: Has the person ever engaged in episodes of harm to people/animals or damage to property (fire setting, vandalism, etc)? If yes, the questions about them should be answered with reference to the attempts in general rather than any specific one, unless otherwise stated.

node.-label: type and seriousness of harm or damage episodes

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever carried out any physical or sexual assaults?
Were any of the episodes physical assaults/abuse?

node.-question: How serious was the most severe physical assault or abuse?

node.-label: most recent violent harm to others
node.-answer-constraint: ((>= [hto >> hto-specific >> hto-past-curr-ep >> hto-type >> hto-phys-sex >> hto-any-violent >> hto-first-time-violent-ep]))
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of assault/physical abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the physical assaults?

node.-label: first time physical harm to others occurred
node.-question: When was the first episode of assault/physical abuse?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-filter-q: Were any of the previous assaults rape or some other form of sexual abuse?

node.-question: Tick the most serious form of sexual assault by the person?
node.-help: This includes forcible fondling, sexual assault with an object, forcible oral or anal intercourse, and forcible rape.

node.-label: most recent episode of sexual assault
node.-answer-constraint: ((>= [hto >> hto-specific >> hto-past-curr-ep >> hto-type >> hto-phys-sex >> hto-any-sex-asslt >> hto-first-time-sexual-ep]))
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of sexual assault?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the episodes of sexual assault?
When was the first episode of sexual assault?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-question: Did any previous episodes of harm to others involve weapons (eg guns, knives)?

node.-label: emotional episodes of harm to others
node.-filter-q: Has the person ever emotionally abused other people (including racial abuse)?
node.-help: Consider verbal abuse, insults, name calling, emotional bullying, constant criticism, humiliation.

node.-label: seriousness of emotional harm to others
node.-question: How serious was the emotional abuse?

node.-label: most recent episode of emotional abuse
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of emotional abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the episodes of emotional abuse?
When was the first episode of emotional abuse?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever engaged in deliberate damage to property (excluding fire setting)?

node.-question: How serious was the damage to property?

node.-label: most recent deliberate damage to property
node.-question: When was the most recent deliberate damage to property?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the episodes of damage to property?

node.-label: first time deliberate damage to property occurred?
node.-question: When was the first deliberate damage to property?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever engaged in fire setting behaviour?

node.-question: How serious were the acts of fire setting?

node.-label: most recent episode of fire setting
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of fire setting?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the fire-setting episodes?
When was the first episode of fire setting?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever abused animals?

node.-question: How serious was the animal abuse?
node.-help: Think about how the person harmed the animal(s), and the seriousness of the injuries inflicted.

node.-label: most recent episode of animal abuse
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of animal abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: How frequent are the episodes of animal abuse?
When was the first episode of animal abuse?
node.-help: This is measuring the duration of the risk behaviour in the person's life as opposed to recency. If recency decreases the duration increases but the effect of recency is much more important on the overall risk judgement.

node.-multiple-tick: ((CARERS-FAMILY "Has anyone been harmed within the domestic setting?" [carers or family]) (SHARED-ACCOM-NEIGHBOURS "Have any neighbours or people sharing your living space been harmed?" [neighbours or people sharing living space])(FRIENDS-COLLEAGUES "Have any friends or colleagues been harmed?" [friends or colleagues]) (HEALTH-WORKERS "Have any health workers been harmed?" [health workers]) (AUTHORITY-FIGS "Have any authority figures been harmed?" [authority figures]) (ETHNIC "Has anyone from a different ethnic background been harmed?" [those from a different ethnic background]))
node.-question: Are there any particular groups of people, rather than complete strangers, that the person is known to have targeted for harm?
node.-help: Select the boxes for all those that apply.

node.-label: person's current perspective on harm or damage episodes
node.-question: Does the person believe there was nothing wrong with causing harm or damage?

node.-label: current harm or damage situation and related behaviour

node.-question: Do you believe the person has an intention/plan to cause harm or damage?

node.-label: means and ability to carry out harm or damage plan
node.-question: Does the person have the means and know-how to carry out the plan for harm or damage?
node.-help: Consider how easy it is for the person to access weapons or any other equipment required for the plan. Does the equipment require specialist skills to use and has the person got them?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no means or know-how") (right "complete means and know-how"))

node.-label: physical steps taken to implement harm or damage plan
node.-question: Has the person taken steps towards implementing the plan to harm or damage (eg made threats, monitored the victim)?

node.-label: planning to harm a particular person
node.-question: Has the person got any particular victims (specific individuals) in mind for harming?

node.-label: appearance indicators of harm or damage
node.-question: Does the person's appearance (not body language or behaviour) cause you concern about risk of harm or damage (eg sweating, blood, state of clothes)?

node.-label: spiritual/religious values/beliefs affecting harm or damage risk
node.-question: What effect do the person's spiritual/religious values or beliefs have on the risk of harm or damage?

node.-label: potential triggers for prospective harm or damage
node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about anything that could trigger harm or damage?

node.-label: potential triggers of harm or damage
node.-question: Is the person exposed to feelings or circumstances that could trigger episodes of harm or damage?

node.-label: potential triggers match those previously triggering harm or damage
node.-question: Do the person's current feelings or circumstances match those that are known to have triggered any previous harm or damage?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no previous harm or damage") (right "current feelings/circumstances identical to those in previous harm or damage"))

node.-question: Does the person have an interest in pursuits related to violence (eg weapons, violent videos or computer games)?

node.-label: family history relating to harm or damage
node.-question: Is there a history of violence, abuse, or aggression in the person's family?
node.-help: Consider criminal history and mental health problems in the person's family.

node.-filter-q: Is the person having thoughts or fantasies about harming people/animals or damaging property?

node.-label: high risk content of harm or damage ideation
node.-question: Does the content of the person's thoughts or fantasies about harm or damage make it more likely he or she will do it?
node.-help: What are the thoughts or fantasies about and how does the content raise alarm bells about harming people/animals or damaging property?  Consider thoughts or fantasies about weapons, destructions, harming people (eg women) or animals.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no change to the likelihood") (right "greatly increased likelihood"))

node.-label: frequency of harm or damage ideation
node.-question: How often do the thoughts or fantasies about harm or damage occur?

node.-label: strength, intensity, intrusiveness, and persistence of harm or damage ideation
node.-question: How persistent, intrusive, or intense are the thoughts/fantasies of harm or damage?
node.-help: Consider the seriousness, intensity, and strength of the violence thoughts, how intrusive or pervasive they are, their persistence, and level of reality or concreteness.
node.-scale-type: ((left "thoughts hardly noticed") (right "can't think about anything else"))

node.-label: thoughts/fantasies of harm or damage linked to real people, events, and circumstances
node.-question: Do the thoughts/fantasies of harm or damage relate to the people, events, and circumstances in the person's own world (ie the realism of the thoughts)?
node.-help: Consider how much the fantasies are based on the person's own world and people in it rather than fictional people, locations and environments that are not linked to those of the person, or scenarios that are completely unrealistic given the person's own capabilities and circumstances.
node.-scale-type: ((left "not based on real life") (right "entirely about real life"))

node.-_FIXME: TODO - replace mg-deviation-threshold attrib with real a real version
node.-question: In your judgement, does the person put any dependents at risk (consider both children and adults)?
node.-help: Consider the risk in the context of the person's circumstances after the assessment if no further action is taken.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's risk to dependents?
Are there any child protection issues?
In your judgement, to what extent is the person failing to look after him or herself?

node.-filter-q: Is the person showing signs of self-neglect?

node.-label: hair and clothing indicative of self neglect
node.-question: Do the person's hair and clothing indicate self-neglect?
node.-help: Consider inappropriateness of clothing (eg inappropriate to the current weather, size is too big, etc), state of clothing (eg tatty or dirty clothing, infested with fleas), worn shoes, dishevelled hair, etc.

node.-question: Does the person have poor personal hygiene (eg smell, dirty hair and nails)?
node.-help: Consider smell (eg body, breath, urine. etc), state of teeth, general cleanliness (eg hair, body, skin, nails, face).

node.-label: recent change in appearance of self neglect
node.-question: Has there been a recent change in appearance suggestive of self-neglect?
To what extent does the person's skin (condition, lesions, injuries, etc) indicate self-neglect?
In your judgement, how vulnerable is the person (consider physical, emotional, sexual, and financial vulnerability)?
Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's vulnerability?

node.-filter-q: Does the person have a history of falls or other accidents?

node.-question: Have any of the falls or accidents occurred recently (within the last year approximately)?

node.-label: causes of falls and accidents known
node.-question: Are the reasons for the falls or accidents known (eg physical health problems, hazards in the home)?
node.-help: The key issue is whether any reasons are still unknown because this will make it difficult to put in place interventions reducing the risk

node.-question: Has the person ever sustained a fragility fracture (broken bone after a minor bump or fall), e.g. wrist, hip, vertebra, humerus?

node.-label: person's appearance and behaviour indicators of vulnerability
node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about appearance or behaviour issues that may be putting the person at risk (consider physical, emotional, sexual, and financial vulnerability)?
Does the person's appearance cause you concern about abuse by others (eg bruises, scratches, blood, state of clothes)?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no suggestion of abuse by others") (right "appearance of extreme abuse"))

node.-label: behaviour causing potential vulnerability to abuse by others

node.-question: Does the person's behaviour make him or her vulnerable to sexual harrassment or abuse?
Does the person's behaviour make him or her vulnerable to physical harrassment or abuse?
Does the person's behaviour make him or her vulnerable to emotional harrassment or abuse?
Does the person's behaviour make him or her vulnerable to financial abuse?
Does the person have a history of wandering behaviour?
node.-help: Consider previous episodes and current situation.

node.-question: Is the person confused or disorientated as a result of recent changes in circumstances (eg hospital admission, new carer)?
node.-help: This question is about temporary cognitive disorders due to a recent change in a person's situation rather than longer-term organic problems that are covered in the mental faculties/cognitive capacity questions.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's ability to live independently?
How much does the person depend on carers?
node.-help: Consider how much the person is reliant on carers for general living requirements

node.-question: Does the person lack the ability to look after daily living requirements (cooking, shopping, cleaning, etc)?
node.-help: Consider lack of ability to maintain safe and clean environment, to look after personal hygiene (eg dressing), ability to budget, cooking skills, etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "able to look after living requirements")(right "totally unable"))

node.-question: These questions are not about specific risks but there are some that may help assess the patient if you have not already decided what to do. Do you wish to answer them now?
Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's feelings/emotions?
Does the person have sudden mood changes or swings?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no sudden mood changes") (right " moods always changing suddenly"))

node.-question: Does the person have negative feelings about him or herself (eg self-hatred, guilt, shame, humiliation)?
Does the person lack any plans for the future?
node.-help: Consider how soon are the plans for (eg next week), how concrete are the plans, etc.

node.-question: Does the person think life is not worth living?
node.-help: This includes having nothing to look forward to, no possibility of change for the better, pessimism, etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "well worth living") (right "not worth living at all"))

node.-question: Is the person displaying anger?
node.-help: This includes person being angry, irritable, frustrated, aggressive, etc.

node.-question: Is the person anxious or fearful?
node.-help: This includes the person feeling panic, fear, insecurity, threat, suspicion, having no trust in themselves.

node.-question: Does the person feel helpless?
node.-help: This includes person feeling trapped, despair, lack of or out of control.

node.-question: Is the person feeling sad or low?
node.-help: This includes person feeling grief, flat, lonely, unhappy.

node.-question: Is the person distressed?
node.-help: This includes person being tormented, agitated, etc.

node.-question: Is the person feeling jealous?
Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's sense of self worth?
node.-help: Consider both grandiose feelings (eg feeling of being powerful/omnipotent, exaggerated self worth, sense of being special) and feelings of worthlessness (nothing to lose, don't care about the consequences), both of which may indicate a propensity for risky behaviours.

node.-question: Does the person feel special and able to control everything?
node.-scale-type: ((left "not particularly special") (right "totally special and in complete control"))

node.-question: Does the person regard him or herself as worthless?
Do you have reason to be concerned about personality factors and their impact on risks?

node.-value-mg: (([suic >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 1) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.3) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 0))) ([sh >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 1) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.3) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 0))) ([sn >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 1) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.3) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 0))) ([hto >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 0) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.1) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0.2) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0.5) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 1))) ([risk-dep >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 0.5) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.3) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0.3)    (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 1))) ([vuln-su >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 1) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.3) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 0)))([absconding >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-assertive] ((NOT-ASSERTIVE 0) (SOMEWHAT-ASSERTIVE 0.1) (NORMALLY-ASSERTIVE 0.2) (VERY-ASSERTIVE 0.5) (EXTREMELY-ASSERTIVE 1))))
node.-question: How assertive is the person?
node.-help: How much are you able to put your views across, insist that others listen to you or to make sure you get what you need from others

node.-question: Does the person lack empathy?
node.-help: Think about what is normal empathy you would expect in people and how much this may be lacking.

node.-question: Is the person overdependent (weak, over-reliant on others, easily influenced, unable to function independently)?

node.-value-mg: (([suic >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 0.5) (disorganised 0.2) (normal 0) (very-organised 0.5)(obsessional-perfectionist 1))) ([sh >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 0.5) (disorganised 0.2) (normal 0) (very-organised 0.5)(obsessional-perfectionist 1))) ([sn >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 1) (disorganised 0.2) (normal 0) (very-organised 0)(obsessional-perfectionist 0))) ([hto >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 0) (disorganised 0) (normal 0) (very-organised 0)(obsessional-perfectionist 0))) ([risk-dep >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 1) (disorganised 0.2) (normal 0) (very-organised 0.1)(obsessional-perfectionist 0.5))) ([vuln-su >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 1) (disorganised 0.2) (normal 0) (very-organised 0.1)(obsessional-perfectionist 0.2)))([absconding >> gen-person-thinking >> gen-personality >> gen-controlling] ((chaotic 0) (disorganised 0) (normal 1) (very-organised 1)(obsessional-perfectionist 0))))
node.-question: How organised is the person's general approach to life?
node.-help: This includes person being regimented, perfectionist, having obsessional traits, or having chaotic approach to organising life.

node.-label: capacity to cope with major life stresses
node.-question: Does the person lack the ability to cope with major life stresses?
How hostile is the person?
node.-help: Think about whether the person tends to be unfriendly, prickly, aggressive or argumentative.

node.-question: How impulsive is the person?
node.-help: not at all, extremely impulsive. Think about how likely you are to do things on the spur of the moment.

node.-question: How unreliable is the person (eg untrustworthy or unpredictable)?
Does the person have a diagnosed personality disorder?

node.-filter-q: Is there any impaired cognitive function (thinking processes, memory, concentration) or dementia?

node.-question: What is the current level of impaired thinking processes and memory?

node.-label: changes in thinking processes and memory
node.-question: Have the thinking processes and memory recently got worse?
node.-help: Consider changes within the last few months, including the person's inability to follow conversation, long silences during conversation with the person, etc. Maximum deterioration should be considered equivalent to full dementia.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no change") (right "recently become totally confused and forgetful"))

node.-question: Is the person able to concentrate?
Do you believe the person has learning disabilities?
node.-help: Think about reading difficulties or inability to solve problems.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's lack of insight and sense of responsibility?
Does the person fail to understand the potential consequences of taking risks?

node.-label: responsibility for impact of behaviour on others
node.-question: Does the person lack any sense of responsibility for the outcomes of risk-taking behaviour?
Does the person lack insight about needing help with mental-health issues?

node.-filter-q: Does the person have any history of depression, mania, hallucinations, or delusions?
Has the person ever been diagnosed with clinical depression?

node.-question: Tick the most appropriate label for the current depression status?
node.-help: First diagnosis - first time the person is known to have suffered from depression; recovery single episode - in recovery from a first period of depression; recovery repeat episodes - in recovery from a repeated period of depression; relapse - the person has gone back into depression having suffered from it previously

node.-filter-q: Is the person currently suffering from mania, hallucinations, or delusions?

node.-question: Is the person displaying manic or hypomanic behaviour (fast speech, excessive irritability, recklessness, impulsivity, etc)?

node.-filter-q: Does the person hear voices that are not present in reality?

node.-question: How much do the voices urge the person to harm or endanger him/herself?
node.-help: Is the person hearing voices that are encouraging suicidal behaviour such as jumping off a bridge? Are the voices threatening the person with dire consequences if they are disobeyed? How influential are the voices (do they represent God or any other figure of authority for the person)?

node.-question: How much do the voices urge the person to harm/endanger other people?

node.-label: likelihood of acting on the voices
node.-question: Will the person act on the voices?
node.-help: Consider ability to distract from and to resist voices, level of belief in voices and will to obey them.

node.-filter-q: Does the person suffer from delusions (ie clearly incorrect and illogical ideas about his or her life and circumstances)?

node.-question: Is the person obsessed about the perceived bad behaviour of particular known people?
node.-help: Examples include an obsession with the partner having an affair, being spied upon by neighbours or the police, believing a neighbour is engaging in child abuse, etc.

node.-question: Is the person obsessed about being harmed or persecuted by particular known people?
node.-help: This includes obsession with imminent death, being infected, people dying without person's intervention, being sexually abused in sleep, persecutory ideas, conspiracy, being watched, etc.

node.-question: How likely is it that the person will act on any delusions?
Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to any physical health problems?

node.-multiple-tick: ((tinnitus "Is tinnitus one of the chronic health conditions?" [tinnitus])(diabetes "Is diabetes one of the chronic health conditions" [diabetes])(multiple-sclerosis "Is multiple sclerosis one of the chronic health conditions?" [multiple sclerosis])(asthma "Is asthma one of the chronic health conditions?" [asthma])(heart-disease "Is heart disease one of the chronic health conditions?" [heart disease])(kidney-disease "Is kidney disease one of the chronic health conditions?" [kidney disease])(lung-disease "Is lung disease one of the chronic health conditions?" [lung disease])(arthritis " Is arthritis one of the chronic health conditions?" [arthritis])(high-blood-pressure "Is high blood pressure one of the chronic health conditions?" [high blood pressure])(other "Are there any other chronic health conditions?" [any other condition]))
node.-question: Does the person suffer from any chronic health conditions?
node.-help: If you ticked 'other' (which is at the bottom of all the conditions so may not be visible without scrolling) then please give the condition in the comment box.

node.-label: when life-threatening or degenerative illness first diagnosed
node.-question: If the person has a life-threatening or degenerative illness (eg cancer, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's, emphysema, HIV), when was it first diagnosed?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: If the person suffers from chronic or periodic pain, how bad is it?
node.-help: Consider the level of pain, how much it affects the person (eg episodic, chronic), treatment of pain (eg poorly controlled), location of pain (eg pain in bones), etc.

node.-question: Does the person suffer from problems that affect mobility and/or dexterity (eg eyesight, balance, disability due to disease or trauma)?
node.-help: Think about the ability to balance, hand-eye co-ordination, any problems linked to sight, hearing, touch, smell etc that might affect movement. Also think about any disabilities affecting muscles, joints, limbs etc. that make it hard to walk, climb stairs, etc.

node.-question: Does the person have trouble communicating as a result of physical health problems (eg hearing, speech)?
Has the person's physical health got worse over the last few months, including temporary or repeating problems?
node.-help: Think about both short and long-term problems e.g. repeated infections and chronic constipation, as well as disability, or disfigurement etc.

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's concordance with health treatment?
Is the person failing to concord with medication or therapies, either deliberately or due to multiple medications, for example?
node.-help: Think about the extent to which health-care advice is followed, or medication or treatment is not taken either deliberately or by mistake, because it is confusing or forgotten.
node.-scale-type: ((left "doing everything as prescribed")(right "not following prescriptions at all"))

node.-label: person's perception of the supportiveness of service received
node.-question: Does the person think health or social care services are not supportive?
Does the person and/or carer think any medication/therapies are not working properly?
node.-help: Consider person's belief in physical side effects (eg weight gain, distress), psychological/emotional side effects (eg hospitalisation is seen as punishment), or faith in services.  Also consider effect of medication/therapies on insight, how soon does the person respond to treatment, level of response (eg successful outcome), etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "working properly or not on medication/treatment")(right "not working at all"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's motivation and engagement with the world?
Is the person physically isolated from the world?
Has the person mentally disengaged or withdrawn from the world?
Does the person lack motivation in general life?
node.-help: Has the person no plans, lack interests, have no desire to change, displays excessive apathy, etc.

node.-label: lack of energy, drive, or enthusiasm
node.-question: Does the person appear listless or lacking energy and drives (eg loss of enthusiasm and libido)?
node.-scale-type: ((left "energetic and enthusiastic")(right "no energy or enthusiasm at all"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's social context (relationships, living arrangements, finances, employment, any detrimental changes)?
Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's current relationships?
Does the person lack a good network of relationships outside the home?
node.-help: Think about people who don't live in the same house, including other family members, friends, neighbours, carers.

node.-question: Does the person lack supportive relationships?
node.-help: This includes proximity and stability in relationships, supportive relationships (eg confiding and caring relationships), relationships that provide security, respect and empathy. Emphasis should be on the importance and centrality of relationships within the family.

node.-question: Does the person have detrimental relationships (eg bullied, over-protected) or ones with people who have antisocial behaviours or who take advantage of the person?
Does the person think important relationships have changed for the worse or soon will do (eg divorce, separation, rows, carer's role, bereavement)?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no changes for the worse") (right "extreme changes for the worse"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's living arrangements?
How often does the person's living place change?
Has the accommodation recently been taken away from the person or is it under threat of being taken away?
What type of supported living does the person have
Is the person's accommodation isolated from other living abodes and resources?
node.-help: This includes ability to reach resources (eg person can't drive).

node.-question: Does the neighbourhood or care environment increase the person's particular risks (eg violent, easy access to drugs and unhelpful temptations)?
node.-help: Consider neighbours, type of neighbourhood (eg inner city, deprived, rough, drug and violent areas), locations tempting risky acts (eg kindergarten), nature of the institution the person may be in, etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no increase in risks") (right "huge increase in risks"))

node.-question: Is the person's accommodation showing lack of care?
node.-help: Consider cleanliness of the home and the general state of repair of objects/furniture within it.

node.-question: Does the person think the accommodation is unfit to live in?
node.-help: This includes warmth, power supply, services or food provided with accommodation.
node.-scale-type: ((left "fit to live in")(right "totally unfit to live in"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about risks due to the person's employment and/or finances?

node.-label: anxiety about perceived level of debts
node.-question: How anxious is the person about perceived levels of debt?
Does the person's income fail to cover the essential living costs of the household (food, rent, heating, etc)?
How unstable is the person's employment history (eg always changing, poor disciplinary record)?
node.-help: Consider person's inability to sustain at work, any work or disciplinary records, etc.

node.-label: recent or potential detrimental change to employment
node.-question: Does the person believe a recent change in employment to be detrimental (eg loss of job, retirement, work stress)?
node.-help: If the assessment is for child/adolescent, consider whether a favourite teacher has left or disliked teachers have arrived, whether the classes have changed meaning friends may be in different ones, or whether certain enjoyed activities such as sports, clubs, and hobbies have been lost. If the young person is in a job, then consider changes in managers or work colleagues.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no change for the worse") (right "really bad changes"))

node.-question: Do you have reason to be concerned about the person's general current behaviour (eg risk-taking, sleep patterns, daily activities, challenging behaviour)?
Does the person take reckless risks (eg with sexual behaviour, driving, gambling and other leisure pursuits)?
Does the person's behaviour lead to unintentional risks (eg fire or harm due to being careless, thoughtless or forgetful; self-injurious behaviour)?
Does the person experience problems with sleeping?
node.-help: This includes insomnia, deprived sleep patterns, etc.

node.-question: Has the person been behaving out of character or unpredictably in recent weeks?
node.-help: Out of character is not a change in mood but something you would not expect from the person's particular personality and the way variations in life circumstances are usually addressed.
node.-scale-type: ((left "not out of character") (right "completely out of character"))

node.-question: Does the person display challenging behaviour (eg antisocial, disruptive, resistance to advice, predatory, false accusations)
node.-help: Think about whether they have no consideration for other people by, for example, making a lot of noise, whether they pester and pursue others inappropriately or take advantage of vulnerable people, etc.

node.-question: Does the person's day lack any structure?
node.-help: Think about whether they have a timetable or regular things to do, be responsible for, or to turn up for. Are the days completely haphazard and unplanned?

node.-label: general level of activity during the day
node.-value-mg: (([suic >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 0.3) (UNDERACTIVE 0.1) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0.5) (HYPERACTIVE 1))) ([sh >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 0.3) (UNDERACTIVE 0.1) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0.5) (HYPERACTIVE 1))) ([sn >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 1) (UNDERACTIVE 0.5) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0) (HYPERACTIVE 0))) ([hto >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 0) (UNDERACTIVE 0) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0.5) (HYPERACTIVE 1))) ([vuln-su >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 1) (UNDERACTIVE 0.5) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0.1) (HYPERACTIVE 0.3)))([absconding >> gen-involve-social >> gen-currnt-bhvr >> gen-day-actvty >> gen-day-actvty-lev] ((INACTIVE 0) (UNDERACTIVE 0) (NORMAL 0) (OVERACTIVE 0.5) (HYPERACTIVE 1))))
node.-question: What is the person's general level of activity?
node.-help: Consider how the person spends his or her leisure time: is he or she slumped in front of the television or spending excessive amounts of time in a passive/inert state? If the person is unemployed, are there any efforts to get a job or fill the time with gainful work? Alternatively, is the person constantly organising and engaging in activities with no time for reflection or rest, behaving hyperactively, with no spare capacity?

node.-question: Does the person fail to eat a healthy diet?
node.-help: This includes the person having very low calorie intake, eating disorders, etc.

node.-question: Is the person's weight a cause of concern? Tick the appropriate description.
Has the person experienced weight change in recent months?
Does the person fail to have appropriate fluid intake (too much or too little)?
node.-scale-type: ((left "fluid intake fine")(right "totally inappropriate fluid intake (too much/too little)"))

node.-filter-q: Does the person have a history of misusing drugs or alcohol?

node.-question: Does alcohol currently have a bad effect on the person's life?
Do drugs currently have a bad effect on the person's life?

node.-filter-q: Does the person have any adverse life events (eg suffered abuse, criminal justice proceedings, detrimental upbringing/education, eating disorders)?
Has the person ever been the victim of any form of abuse (eg physical, sexual, financial, emotional)?
Has the person ever been sexually abused?

node.-label: most recent episode of sexual abuse
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of sexual abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: Was the first episode of sexual abuse during childhood or early adolescence?

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever been physically abused?

node.-label: most recent episode of physical abuse
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of physical abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: Was the first episode of physical abuse during childhood or early adolescence?

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever been emotionally abused due to, for example, race, religion, sexual orientation, appearance?
node.-help: This includes the person being verbally abused, insulted, called names, emotionally bullied, constantly criticised, humiliated, etc.

node.-label: most recent episode of emotional abuse
node.-question: When was the most recent episode of emotional abuse?
node.-help: Don't worry if you don't know the exact date. An approximate date or just the year and/or month is fine.

node.-question: Was the first episode of emotional abuse during childhood or early adolescence?
Has the person ever been financially abused?

node.-filter-q: Has the person ever faced serious criminal justice proceedings (court cases, custodial sentences, etc)?

node.-question: Are the serious criminal justice proceedings current?
Did the person grow up in emotionally disturbed or disruptive environments?
node.-help: This includes difficult, violent, and chaotic, environments or ones with poor emotional attachments.

node.-question: Has the person suffered from eating disorders in the past?
Did the person have a bad time at school?
node.-help: Consider poor achievements, educational problems, bullying, unpleasant teachers, etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "no problems with school") (right "terrible time at school"))

node.-filter-q: Are you concerned about the person's behavioural presentation with respect to potential risks (eg verbal and physical behaviour, uneasy `gut' feeling in yourself)?
Are you concerned about the person's engagement with you during the assessment?

node.-question: How difficult is it to have rapport with the person?
Is the person unwilling to communicate or respond to questions?
node.-help: Consider how cooperative the person is (eg talks about problems/issues, tells you what you want to hear), time taken to respond, ability to handle questions appropriately (eg hostility to probing questions), uncommunicative (mute, withdrawn, not open, not answering), withholding information (eg person's plans, feelings, degree of withholding) etc.

node.-question: Do you have an uneasy 'gut' feeling about the person (eg about the person's honesty, something doesn't quite add up, something missing)?
node.-scale-type: ((left "no uneasy gut feeling") (right "extremely uneasy gut feeling"))

node.-filter-q: Are you concerned about verbal indicators of risk?

node.-question: How aggressive/hostile is the person's tone of voice?
node.-help: Consider the tone of voice (threatening, angry, etc); is the person shouting or, in contrast, very quite and matter of fact?

node.-question: How depressed and downbeat is the person's tone of voice?

node.-label: degree to which the person is making sense
node.-question: Is the person failing to make sense (eg incoherent, irrational)?

node.-filter-q: Are you concerned about the person's body language and expression?

node.-question: Does the person's body language indicate distress?
node.-help: This includes person being hunched, tearful, fidgety, or preoccupied, having agitated movements or head in hands.

node.-label: movements, posture, facial expression indicating low mood
node.-question: Do the person's movements, posture, and facial expression indicate a low, downbeat, or gloomy mood?
node.-help: This includes person being sleepy, restless, hunched, unsmiling, gloomy or morose, having stooped posture, head down, or head in hands.

node.-question: How aggressive or threatening are the person's movements and posture?
node.-help: This includes person sitting forward, clenching fists, pacing, getting very close, banging fists, digging nails into hands, etc.
node.-scale-type: ((left "not aggressive or threatening")(right "extremely aggressive or threatening"))

node.-question: Does the person appear detached or preoccupied?
node.-scale-type: ((left "not detached or preoccupied") (right "extremely detached or preoccupied"))

node.-question: Does the person avoid eye contact?
node.-help: consider avoidance that is deliberate or indicative of non-normal behaviour rather than something that may be cultural.

node.-value-mg: (([suic >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([sh >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([sn >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([hto >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([risk-dep >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([vuln-su >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 1) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))) ([absconding >> gen-presentation >> gen-body-face >> gen-eyes >> gen-eye-movement] ((UNRESPONSIVE-GLAZED 0) (APPROPRIATE 0) (FIXED-STARING 1) (DARTING 1))))
node.-question: How would you describe the person's general eye movement?

node.-label: congruence of physical, verbal, and emotional presentation
node.-question: How inconsistent are the person's physical, verbal, and emotional presentations (lack of congruence)?
Date of birth

node.-value-mg: (([suic >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 1) (FEMALE 0))) ([sh >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 0) (FEMALE 1))) ([sn >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 1) (FEMALE 0))) ([hto >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 1) (FEMALE 0))) ([risk-dep >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 1) (FEMALE 0))) ([vuln-su >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 0) (FEMALE 1)))([absconding >> gen-demog >> gen-gender] ((MALE 1) (FEMALE 0))))
node.-question: Gender

node.-filter-q: Does the person have a partner?

node.-question: Does the person live with his or her partner?

node.-label: occupants sharing accommodation other than a partner
node.-filter-q: Does the person share the living accommodation with anyone who is not the partner?
Does the person live with dependents (relatives or children)?

node.-question: How many dependents does the person live with
What is the age of the youngest dependent?
How many non-dependents share the living accommodation
node.-help: This includes partner, carer, friends/communal, sibling(s), parent(s), and other relative(s).

node.-question: What is the person's ethnic group?
Does the person have any Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA)?
node.-help: Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) are for people under the remit of responsible authorities for managing serious risks to the public.
